Award.AwardTitle: Printed Organic Layers for Integrated Electronics: controlling processing to achieve stability and reproducibility

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to demonstrate reliable deposition of solution processed electronic materials over large areas in order to obtain stable device performance and allow integration of components of sensing systems that are mechanically flexible. The program will investigate methods of obtaining stability at every step of device fabrication: ink formulation, ink deposition, solvent removal, thin film morphology and device electrical stability.

The intellectual merit is the demonstration of reliable and stable fabrication of printed flexible electronics. The program will address two of the most challenging aspects of printing electronics: reliable deposition of multi-layers and device-to-device variations. A process for suspending semiconducting polymers as nanoparticle dispersions in water will be developed and as a consequence allow layer-to-layer deposition from benign solvents with high interfacial quality. Device stability and reliability will be studied in two types of structures; photodiodes and thin film transistors.

The broader impacts are contributions to the fundamental understanding of materials processing and device fabrication using printing. The goal of developing reliable printing conditions over large flexible areas is applicable to a range of electronic devices and sensors based on organic materials. The approach of processing organic materials from aqueous nanoparticle dispersion will enable the demonstration of precise deposition of multiple polymer layers from solution. The PI is engaged with several outreach programs that offer research experiences to high school teachers and students. Within this program, simple printed electronic devices will be developed and integrated with existing educational programs targeting the enrichment of pre-college education.

Institution.Name: University of California-Berkeley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed modeling and experimental process design tools to achieve high performance and reliability of organic devices. An empirically based modeling program to accurately simulate novel materials used in photovoltaic devices and transparent conductive films of single-walled carbon nanotubes for use as transparent electrodes in organic optoelectronics.  The main goal of the project was the demonstration of electronic devices, fabricated on flexible substrates, fabricated only by printing techniques with high fabrication yield. A process was demonstrated for surface energy-guided blade coating and used in conjunction with inkjet printing to fabricate all-printed high performance, high yield, and low variability organic thin film transistor (OTFT) arrays on plastic substrates. These arrays of flexible OTFTs are currently been applied to large area image sensors and as building blocks for printed circuits.  A combination of blade coating and screen printing is used to fabricate all-printed organic flexible photodiodes, tuning the thicknesses of the active layer and cathode interlayer to achieve high detectivity and high yield. High fabrication yield and good reproducibility were achieved by studying the film characteristics for each printed layer of the devices. One broad technical impact of the research is the study of printable electrodes for photodiodes and photovoltaic devices. We have reported on the use of spray coated carbon nanotube films for transparent electrodes in flexible solar cells and the use of interlayers to modify the work function of PEDOT in fully printed photodiodes. This results into two different alternatives for ITO free devices, improving the life time when substrates are bent. The high reproducibility and high device yield also allowed the demonstration of flexible integrated systems that could have an impact on wearable medical devices. Printed photodiodes were integrated with organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) in a pulse oximeter. Highly flexible thin-film lithium-ion batteries based on carbon nanotube current collectors are used as power sources. In addition, flexible screen-printed inductors and resistors were designed for power electronics applications and demonstrated in a step-up voltage regulator circuit, which was used to power OLEDs from a flexible battery.


Last Modified: 03/01/2016
Modified by: Ana Arias

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We have developed modeling and experimental process design tools to achieve high performance and reliability of organic devices. An empirically based modeling program to accurately simulate novel materials used in photovoltaic devices and transparent conductive films of single-walled carbon nanotubes for use as transparent electrodes in organic optoelectronics. The main goal of the project was the demonstration of electronic devices, fabricated on flexible substrates, fabricated only by printing techniques with high fabrication yield. A process was demonstrated for surface energy-guided blade coating and used in conjunction with inkjet printing to fabricate all-printed high performance, high yield, and low variability organic thin film transistor (OTFT) arrays on plastic substrates. These arrays of flexible OTFTs are currently been applied to large area image sensors and as building blocks for printed circuits. A combination of blade coating and screen printing is used to fabricate all-printed organic flexible photodiodes, tuning the thicknesses of the active layer and cathode interlayer to achieve high detectivity and high yield. High fabrication yield and good reproducibility were achieved by studying the film characteristics for each printed layer of the devices. One broad technical impact of the research is the study of printable electrodes for photodiodes and photovoltaic devices. We have reported on the use of spray coated carbon nanotube films for transparent electrodes in flexible solar cells and the use of interlayers to modify the work function of PEDOT in fully printed photodiodes. This results into two different alternatives for ITO free devices, improving the life time when substrates are bent. The high reproducibility and high device yield also allowed the demonstration of flexible integrated systems that could have an impact on wearable medical devices. Printed photodiodes were integrated with organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) in a pulse oximeter. Highly flexible thin-film lithium-ion batteries based on carbon nanotube current collectors are used as power sources. In addition, flexible screen-printed inductors and resistors were designed for power electronics applications and demonstrated in a step-up voltage regulator circuit, which was used to power OLEDs from a flexible battery.
